answers: gamma correction [or gamma encoding; or gamma compression]
far ultraviolet [or UV light; accept Ultra Violet]
titanium dioxide [or TiO2]
parts: Name this digital image processing technique, which applies the inverse of the tonal curve that shapes a monitor's display brightness in order to correct the encoding of color values.

The 2018 Pantone Color of the Year was a pun on this portion of the electromagnetic spectrum. In stereolithography, polymers are "cured" by lamps in this range, which has a lower frequency than gamma and X-rays.

This white chemical compound absorbs UV light without reflecting visible light, so it's often added to sunscreen. Semiconductor photocatalysis uses nanoparticles of this compound, which forms the mineral anatase.

answers: Martin Scorsese [or Martin Charles "Marty" Scorsese] (The historical drama was The Irishman.)
Quentin Tarantino [or Quentin Jerome Tarantino]
Nuri Bilge Ceylan ("jay-LAHN")
parts: Leone's later film Once Upon a Time in America was restored by this director, whose World Cinema Project has distributed films like A Brighter Summer Day and Mysterious Object at Noon. A historical drama by this director adapted the unverified book I Heard You Paint Houses.
This director restored period details of 1969 LA but altered Sharon Tate's fate in his 2019 film about the Manson family murders, Once Upon a Time in Hollywood.
This Turkish director of the Chekhov-inspired film Winter Sleep used a group's murder investigation to frame humorous observations of quotidian rural life in Once Upon a Time in Anatolia.

answers: Lithuania [or Lietuva; or Republic of Lithuania; or Lietuvos Respublika] (The vigilante was Adolfas Ramanauskas.)
Masha Gessen [or Maria Alexandrovna Gessen]
pogroms [accept the Kaunas pogrom]
parts: Name this country where Rūta Vanagaitė (“vah-nah-GUY-tay”) has made enemies by challenging myths about the Forest Brothers, who are commonly hailed as World War II-era heroes.

Vanagaitė has been profiled by this Russian-American reporter who wrote a viral blog post after Trump's election warning "do not be taken in by small signs of normality." This author wrote the 2020 book Surviving Autocracy.

A 2020 bill in Lithuania honored Juozas Lukša-Daumantas ("YOO-oh-zuss LOOK-sha DOH-mun-tuss"), a World War II partisan whose anti-Soviet Lithuanian Activist Front perpetrated one of these massacres of Jews in Kaunas.

answers: Marie Kondo [or Kondō Marie; accept KonMari]
Sweden [or Kingdom of Sweden; or Konungariket Sverige; accept The Gentle Art of Swedish Death Cleaning]
Bullet Journal [or word forms like bullet journaling; or Bujo]
parts: This Japanese woman famously recommended throwing out any object that does not "spark joy" in The Life-Changing Magic of Tidying Up. She now has a Netflix show.

An author from this country wrote a best-seller on its namesake "Gentle Art of Death Cleaning," which involves getting rid of most of your possessions so that your relatives don't have to do so after you die.

Ryder Carroll developed this trendy analog system for helping you make better to-do lists. Carroll's 2018 book titled for this system promises to help you "Track the Past, Order the Present, Design the Future."

answers: H Is for Hawk
Joan Didion
Jesmyn Ward (The novel is Salvage the Bones.)
parts: Identify this memoir by Helen Macdonald that explores how the author uses Mabel, the title creature, to deal with grief following the unexpected death of her father.
This author's grief memoir The Year of Magical Thinking chronicles the aftermath of the death of her husband, John Gregory Dunne. She also wrote The White Album.

Dwight Garner described this author's memoir, Men We Reaped, as "a book about scars;" it traces the deaths of five young men from her childhood. She won the 2011 National Book Award for a novel whose protagonist Esch lives in Bois Sauvage, Mississippi.

answers: crime drop [or decline in crime rates in the early 1990s; or equivalents; accept answers about crime declines in the US or internationally; accept declines in specific crimes like decline in homicides; accept The Great American Crime Decline; accept The Myth of the 'Crime Decline': Exploring Change and Continuity in Crime and Harm] (The ICVS is the International Crime Victims Survey used by many studies.)
lead [or Pb; accept lead paint or lead abatement or lead poisoning; accept leaded gasoline or tetraethyllead or TEL; accept "Lead: America's Real Criminal Element"]
ATSDR [or Agency for Toxic Substances and Disease Registry]
parts: Identify this trend that Franklin Zimring compared in the US and Canada. The Brennan Center attributed this trend to consumer confidence, the program CompStat, an aging population, and reduced alcohol intake.
A Mother Jones story by Kevin Drum popularized the hypothesis that crime declined because the Clean Air Act helped phase this element out of gasoline.

In Confronting Environmental Racism, Janet Phoenix cites vast disparities in lead paint exposure among Black and white kids using data from NHANES ("n-hayns"), HUD, and this agency created by the Superfund law. CDC directors also run this agency, which reclaims brownfields and runs registries for asbestos and ALS.

answers: free ports [or free economic zones; or free economic territories; or free zones; or free trade zones; prompt on special economic zones]
Wilmington, Delaware [accept Wilmington Blue Rocks]
Amedeo Modigliani [or Amedeo Clemente Modigliani]
parts: Identify these special locations where art and other goods can be exchanged tax-free. US Customs oversees the 200 or so locations of this type in the US.

One of the largest free ports in the US is located in this East Coast city, whose minor-league baseball team plays at Daniel S. Frawley Stadium and has three mascots, one of which is Rocky Bluewinkle.
A Nazi-seized painting by this artist was recovered from a Swiss free port. Meryle Secrest wrote a 2011 life of this Italian artist, who was fond of painting elongated faces in works like Red Nude.

answers: orphan drugs [accept orphan receptors; accept Orphan Drug Act of 1983]
lysosome

acid alpha-glucosidase [or alpha-1,4-glucosidase; or alpha-D-glucosidase; or GAA; or glucosidase alpha; or acid maltase; accept ATGAA; accept alpha-glucosidase inhibitors; prompt on glucosidases or glycoside hydrolases or glycosyl hydrolases or GHs; accept glucoinvertase or glucosidosucrase or maltase-glucoamylase or alpha-glucopyranosidase or glucosidoinvertase or alpha-D-glucoside glucohydrolase]
parts: Identify this term for drugs whose target disease is too rare to incentivize pharmaceutical research. The 2002 Rare Diseases Act updated a 1983 Act named for these drugs, which include Cerliponase alfa for Batten disease.
Some countries designate glucocerebrosidase enzyme-replacement therapy as an orphan drug for Gaucher's disease, one of many inborn errors of metabolism affecting this acidified organelle.

The FDA granted the "breakthrough therapy" designation to a recombinant form of this enzyme's "acid" form to treat the lysosomal storage disease Pompe disease. Type 2 diabetes may be treated with oral inhibitors of this enzyme like Acarbose.

answers: skin whitening [accept equivalents like skin lightening or skin bleaching or skin brightening or "fairness cream"; prompt on general answers like skincare or skin creams or cosmetics or beauty or sunscreen or equivalents]
Indonesia [or Republic of Indonesia; or Republik Indonesia]
Ghana [or Republic of Ghana]
parts: Identify this goal of billion-dollar Asian products that include Korea's Innisfree and Laneige ("la-NEZH") brands. Products for this purpose often contain kojic acid, glutathione, and hydroquinone.

Although many people in this country prize "putih" ("poo-TEE") or white skin, its soldiers regularly sunbathe to fight off disease. Saudi Arabia has heavily financed Islamist groups in this most populous Muslim-majority country.

Jemima Pierre's The Predicament of Blackness examines postcolonial skin lightening in this country. Chinese migrants engage in illegal mining called "galamsey" ("gal-um-SAY") in this African country, where China has financed trawlers to catch illegal saiko fish.

answers: Cochrane Collaboration
meta-analysis [or meta-research or meta-study]
Stanford University [or Leland Stanford Junior University] (The CCRMA is the Center for Computer Research in Music and Acoustics.)
parts: Name this British organization that publishes systematic reviews and "plain language summaries" to communicate evidence-based information about health.
Cochrane also publishes findings from studies described by this adjective. These "analyses" pool results from multiple studies to calculate a summary effect size and its precision.

John Ioannidis ("yo-ANN-id-iss"), a director of this university's Meta-Research Innovation Center and a COVID-19 contrarian, criticized "the mass production of redundant… systematic reviews and meta‐analyses." This university's interdisciplinary centers include ChEM-H and the CCRMA.

answers: The Washington Post [or WaPo; or the Washington Post Company; prompt on The Post] (The billionaire is Jeff Bezos.)
CNN [or Cable News Network]
E. J. Dionne [or Eugene Joseph Dionne, Jr.]
parts: Identify this media company. The billionaire who owns this company may have been denied the JEDI contract for his most prominent business because of critical stories it ran.

Washington Post columnist Fareed Zakaria was put under review in 2012 when he admitted to plagiarizing another writer's article about gun control. Zakaria also hosts a namesake GPS on this cable network that hit it big during the Gulf War.

This liberal Catholic Washington Post columnist's wide-ranging works include One Nation After Trump, a book about "reclaiming faith and politics" titled Souled Out, and the influential Why Americans Hate Politics.

answers: sanitary napkins [or sanitary pads; accept tampons; accept feminine hygiene products; accept anything involving a menstruation product] (The documentary is Period. End of Sentence.)
Akshay Kumar [or Rajiv Hari Om Bhatia]
value-added tax
parts: Identify these goods. A 2019 Oscar went to a short documentary by Rayka Zehtabchi that chronicled making these products easily available in the Indian village of Hapur.
This Bollywood actor starred in the 2018 film Pad Man, loosely based on the life of inventor Arunachalam Muruganantham. He starred alongside Ileana D'Cruz in the 2016 film Rustom.

In 2018, British women used blood-stained items to press Parliament to remove this type of tax from feminine hygiene products. Unlike a sales tax, this tax, which is abbreviated VAT, is imposed at different parts of production.

answers: Fourth Industrial Revolution [prompt on Industrial Revolution; accept Industry 4.0]
social media [accept social networking sites; prompt on The Social Dilemma; anti-prompt on specific social media sites or apps]
human attention [accept attention-extraction model; accept The Attention Merchants: The Epic Scramble to Get Inside Our Heads; accept How to Do Nothing: Resisting the Attention Economy]
parts: Identify this three-word phrase coined by the World Economic Forum's Klaus Schwab for a period altered by gene editing, automation, and integrated "cyber physical systems."

Schwab warned that one danger of the Fourth Industrial Revolution is a "spiral of silence" identified by Sherry Turkle as a way that feeds on these websites are polarized. A 2020 Netflix documentary examines their "dilemma."

The Social Dilemma traces numerous issues to the model "extracting" this thing, which is a scarce resource exploited by modern "merchants" according to Tim Wu. Jenny Odell's book How to Do Nothing advises us to resist the "economy" around this thing.

answers: real estate [or property; accept answers like houses or homes or buildings or apartments or land]
Vancouver, British Columbia
Moneyland
parts: Identify this industry whose MLS cartel is being investigated by the Department of Justice for keeping transaction costs artificially high.
This temperate Canadian city, nicknamed "Hollywood North," passed the first empty homes tax in North America due to skyrocketing foreign real estate investment, especially from China.

This Oliver Bullough book details how the super-rich launder ill-gotten gains into luxury real estate. This book's title place is a "virtual country where, if you're rich enough… the laws do not apply to you."

answers: Jake Heggie
"The Star-Spangled Banner" [or answers indicating the United States national anthem] (The performance was by Whitney Houston.)
Philip Glass
parts: Name this composer of the operas Dead Man Walking and Moby-Dick.

The title character's younger rival in Great Scott, Tatyana Bakst, performs this song in a bel canto style. A landmark January 1991 performance of this song changed its time signature from 3/4 to 4/4 on advice from Rickey Minor.
Heggie is second to this man in the number of performances for American-composed operas. He worked on the score for the 2015 Fantastic Four film and composed the opera Einstein on the Beach.

answers: Sabrina
graphic novel [prompt on comic book]
Canada (Dave Sim created Cerebus.)
parts: Identify this work that features several monologues from radio host Albert Douglas on the murder of the title character by a 23-year-old man named Timmy Yancey. This work by Nick Drnaso ("dur-NASS-oh") was nominated for the Booker Prize.
Sabrina is this kind of work. The musical Fun Home was based on an autobiographical work of this type by Alison Bechdel.

Sabrina is published by Drawn and Quarterly, a publisher based in this country. Mariko Tamaki's graphic novel This One Summer was based on a cottage she visited as a kid in this country, which is the birthplace of the creator of the comic Cerebus.

answers: Cape floristic region [or CFR or Cape Phytochorion; or Cape Floral Kingdom; accept Fynbos and Renosterveld but prompt on fynbos; accept Cape of Good Hope; prompt on South African Kingdom or equivalents]
tea [accept specific kinds of tea; accept chá]
Burundi [or Republic of Burundi; or Republika y'Uburundi; or République du Burundi] (Gitega replaced Bujumbura as the capital.)
parts: Name this tiny floristic region whose many endemic plants include Elegia and blushing bride. The sugarbird Promerops cafer pollinates this floral kingdom's iconic king protea plant.

In 2019, Khoi and San activists demanded profits from the Cape floristic region's rooibos ("ROY-boss"), which is harvested for this drink. Starbucks has recently pushed versions of this non-coffee drink like a Matcha Green Latte.

Kenya and Uganda's dominance of African tea exports has been challenged by plantations like Teza near this country's Kibira National Park on the Congo-Nile Divide. In 2019, this landlocked country's capital moved to the former seat of King Ntare V.

answers: Diller Scofidio + Renfro [or DSR]
New York City [or NYC: accept Manhattan]
Catholic Church [accept The Vatican; prompt on the church or Christianity]
parts: Identify this architecture firm behind the planned Centre of Music in London and the recently opened Shed. It’s named for three partners.
Diller Scofidio + Renfro's Shed and High Line are both in this city. The High Line passes through its Chelsea neighborhood.

DSR designed a 2018 exhibit for the Met's Costume Institute themed around this organization, part of which was staged at the Cloisters. Ross Douthat ("DAO-thut"), who has written a book on this institution, was one of three New York Times critics to judge the show.

answers: Eimear McBride
Ireland [or Republic of Ireland; or Éire; or Poblacht na hÉireann]
The Gathering
parts: Name this author whose distinctive style permeates her novel A Girl Is a Half-formed Thing, whose protagonist suffers horrific abuses while caring for her disabled brother. A drama student has a troubled relationship with an older actor in her novel The Lesser Bohemians.
McBride hails from this country, whose literary luminaries include Sebastian Barry, Roddy Doyle, and Colm Tóibín ("CALL-um toh-BEAN").
Irish author Anne Enright won the 2007 Booker Prize for this novel, which centers on the enormous Hegarty family returning to Dublin for the wake of Liam, who drowned himself in Brighton.

answers: Ethiopia [or Federal Democratic Republic of Ethiopia; or yeʾĪtiyoṗṗya Fēdēralawī Dēmokirasīyawī Rīpebilīk; or other variants] (PM Abiy Ahmed won the Nobel Peace Prize.)

cheating on school exams [accept equivalents like academic dishonesty or giving students answers to tests; prompt on answers like posing as someone else by asking "for what purpose?"] (The Michael B. Jordan project is Wrong Answer.)
Halie Selassie I [or Lij Tafari Makonnen; prompt on Makonnen]
parts: Name this country that is roughly tied with Iran and Syria for the least free internet outside of China. However, this country's Prime Minister, from the EPRDF, won a 2019 award in part for relaxing censorship.
Ethiopia has annually shut down its internet to prevent this behavior. Michael B. Jordan is working on a film about widespread instances of this behavior in Atlanta overseen by Beverly Hall.

Protesters in London destroyed a statue of this Ethiopian ruler following the 2020 murder of Hachalu Hundessa and subsequent internet shutdown in Addis Ababa. His image still graces many reggae T-shirts.
